posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked: We’re looking for suggestions for an elevator latch that allows the elevator to start fully down once at the start of the match, but then once the elevator goes up, to set a new mechanical bottom for the elevator.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked: Any reason it can’t be limited by software only?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.custom_user_title: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked:
Good question!  Our robot design is based upon the Rust Hounds RI3D . RustHOUNDS Ri3D 2025

The elevator is continuously rigged. The “pen” that holds the coral is on the first moving stage. The moving Arm and  End Effector “plunger” that captures the coral is on the second moving stage.  The plunging action of the Arm pointing straight down and elevator plunging the second stage strait down into first stage does not happen until the first stage has gone fully down (because of the continuous rigging).

By latching the bottom of the first stage higher on the elevator, we can reduce our elevator motion that is required to plunge, reducing our cycle time.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked: will you still need the first moving stage to return to the true bottom of the elevator to receive coral?  Or did you change where the funnel leads?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.custom_user_title: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
you could possibly put a limit switch on the stationary support of the elevator and have a pin or something attached to the coral stage that triggers it the first time it goes by and zeros out the lower to that height in the software. Then when you return down, it will see that level as your software end stop.

Just a quick thought as I read your post.

If you are are wanting a physical stop, you could possibly use a spring loaded pin of some sort that pops out on both sides as your coral section lifts past it on its first move. It would have to be reset in the pits between matches.

posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked: No, we only need to be at the bottom in the starting configuration. Our funnel feeds much higher on the elevator than the Rust Hounds design, reducing the energy in the coral has when it hits the pen.

posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked:
Yes, an approach to a spring loaded pin or foot that can attach to the outer frame of an elevator and be mechanically stiff enough to be a new bottom stop for the first elevator stage is what we’re looking for.

In the pits, we would raise the elevator a bit, depress the pin/foot, and lower the first stage to the true bottom.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked:
Can you screw something like this right into the side rail? Innovative Components Pull Knob, 1/2" Tip Dia., 0.560"L, Pull Knob GI1/2S2.25-BPL5 | Zoro

The first stage can compress the pin out of the way until you move high enough for it to release and then act as a mechanical stop.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.custom_user_title: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked: Without seeing your robot it will be hard to design something for you. Are you using pneumatics on your robot? How much higher do you need the new bottom to be?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Maybe a strip (or two) of 1/4" polycarb that is flexed out of the way when you are starting, and pops into the right place to be the stop the first time your elevator goes up?  It probably doesn’t need to go very far in to work on an elevator.  There’s going to be a limit to the buckling strength of it, but, its simple…

We are using a flexing polycarb latch on our retractable funnel, which is why I was thinking about it

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked:
Nomads 6995 has a nice way to do it using a WCP brake without pneumatics, but instead on a folding arm. IMG_4850 2250×3000 9.63 MB

IMG_4850 2250×3000 9.63 MB

IMG_4850 2250×3000 9.63 MB

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked: Which picture represents where you start and which represents where you want your “new” position to be?

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked: At first glance the “simplest” method might be to add a hinged piece to the lower support of the first stage such that as you lift the elevator up, the spacer drops into place effectively moving your physical end stop. No motors or pneumatics required and doesn’t weigh much.

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked:
This was my first thought as well. For some reference, 254 did something similar in 2023 but just in the opposite direction to start higher in order to place the preload quicker: Team 254 Presents: 2023 BREAKDOWN - Technical Binder, Code, Q&A - #39 by Torrance

In your case, this could just be a mechanism that snaps into the path of the carriage rather than out of it.
